title: Investor at $1.1bn tech fund Laurel Bowden warns of WeWork 'adjustment' to start-up values
text:
Anglo-Israeli technology investor 83North has raised $300m (£243m) in fresh funding to tackle Europe's start-ups, bringing its total raised to $1.1bn, as one of its veteran investors warned of soaring valuations at technology start-ups.

The fund, spun out and rebranded from heavyweight Silicon Valley fund Greylock in 2015, invests in software start-ups including food delivery ventures, financial technology and data.

It was previously an early backer of Just Eat, ahead of its 2014 initial public offering, and Sweden's iZettle, which was sold last year to US payments giant PayPal for $2.2bn.

The partners are split between its London office in Mayfair and Tel Aviv, with the London office largely represented by veteran investor Laurel Bowden.

Ms Bowden said the firm remained cautious over soaring valuations at companies such as WeWork, which recently pulled out of its planned $47bn initial public offering, as well as challenger banks in the UK market, which include the likes of Monzo and Revolut.

The investor said there would likely be “an adjustment” to valuations “with what has happened with Uber and WeWork”.
description: Anglo-Israeli technology investor 83North has raised $300m (£243m) in fresh funding to tackle Europe's start-ups, bringing its total raised to $1.
